segment.source: Apps use background tasks and two main mechanisms to maintain communications when they are not in the foreground: The socket broker, and control channel triggers.
segment.target: Apps use background tasks and two main mechanisms to maintain communications when they are not in the foreground: The socket broker, and control channel triggers.

segment.source: Network communications in the background
segment.target: Network communications in the background

segment.source: Network communications in the background
segment.target: Network communications in the background

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: SocketActivityTrigger
segment.target: SocketActivityTrigger

segment.source: ControlChannelTrigger
segment.target: ControlChannelTrigger

segment.source: Apps use background tasks and two main mechanisms to maintain communications when they are not in the foreground: The socket broker, and control channel triggers.
segment.target: Apps use background tasks and two main mechanisms to maintain communications when they are not in the foreground: The socket broker, and control channel triggers.

segment.source: Apps that use sockets can delegate ownership of a socket to a system socket broker when they leave the foreground.
segment.target: Apps that use sockets can delegate ownership of a socket to a system socket broker when they leave the foreground.

segment.source: The broker then activates the app when traffic arrives on the socket, transfers ownership back to the app, and the app processes the arriving traffic.
segment.target: The broker then activates the app when traffic arrives on the socket, transfers ownership back to the app, and the app processes the arriving traffic.

segment.source: Socket broker and the SocketActivityTrigger
segment.target: Socket broker and the SocketActivityTrigger

segment.source: If your app uses DatagramSocket, StreamSocket, or StreamSocketListener connections, then you should use SocketActivityTrigger and the socket broker to be notified when traffic arrives for your app while it's not in the foreground.
segment.target: If your app uses DatagramSocket, StreamSocket, or StreamSocketListener connections, then you should use SocketActivityTrigger and the socket broker to be notified when traffic arrives for your app while it's not in the foreground.

segment.source: In order for your app to receive and process data received on a socket when your app is not active, your app must perform some one-time setup at startup, and then transfer socket ownership to the socket broker when it is transitioning to a state where it is not active.
segment.target: In order for your app to receive and process data received on a socket when your app is not active, your app must perform some one-time setup at startup, and then transfer socket ownership to the socket broker when it is transitioning to a state where it is not active.

segment.source: The one-time setup steps are:
segment.target: The one-time setup steps are:

segment.source: Create a SocketActivityTrigger and register a background task for the trigger with the TaskEntryPoint parameter set to your code for processing a received packet.
segment.target: Create a SocketActivityTrigger and register a background task for the trigger with the TaskEntryPoint parameter set to your code for processing a received packet.

segment.source: Call EnableTransferOwnership on the socket, before you bind the socket.
segment.target: Call EnableTransferOwnership on the socket, before you bind the socket.

segment.source: The action to take at suspend is:
segment.target: The action to take at suspend is:

segment.source: When your app is about to suspend, call TransferOwnership on the socket to transfer it to a socket broker.
segment.target: When your app is about to suspend, call TransferOwnership on the socket to transfer it to a socket broker.

segment.source: The broker monitors the socket and activates your background task when data is received.
segment.target: The broker monitors the socket and activates your background task when data is received.

segment.source: The following example includes a utility TransferOwnership function to perform the transfer for StreamSocketListener sockets.
segment.target: The following example includes a utility TransferOwnership function to perform the transfer for StreamSocketListener sockets.

segment.source: (Note that the different types of sockets each have their own TransferOwnership method, so you must call the method appropriate for the socket whose ownership you are transferring.
segment.target: (Note that the different types of sockets each have their own TransferOwnership method, so you must call the method appropriate for the socket whose ownership you are transferring.

segment.source: Your code would probably contain an overloaded TransferOwnership helper with one implementation for each socket type you use, so that the OnSuspending code remains easy to read.)
segment.target: Your code would probably contain an overloaded TransferOwnership helper with one implementation for each socket type you use, so that the OnSuspending code remains easy to read.)

segment.source: An app transfers ownership of a socket to a socket broker and passes the ID for the background task using the appropriate one of the following methods:
segment.target: An app transfers ownership of a socket to a socket broker and passes the ID for the background task using the appropriate one of the following methods:

segment.source: One of the TransferOwnership methods on a DatagramSocket.
segment.target: One of the TransferOwnership methods on a DatagramSocket.

segment.source: One of the TransferOwnership methods on a StreamSocket.
segment.target: One of the TransferOwnership methods on a StreamSocket.

segment.source: One of the TransferOwnership methods on a StreamSocketListener.
segment.target: One of the TransferOwnership methods on a StreamSocketListener.

segment.source: In your background task's event handler:
segment.target: In your background task's event handler:

segment.source: First, get a background task deferral so that you can handle the event using asynchronous methods.
segment.target: First, get a background task deferral so that you can handle the event using asynchronous methods.

segment.source: Next, extract the SocketActivityTriggerDetails from the event arguments, and find the reason that the event was raised:
segment.target: Next, extract the SocketActivityTriggerDetails from the event arguments, and find the reason that the event was raised:

segment.source: If the event was raised because of socket activity, create a DataReader on the socket, load the reader asynchronously, and then use the data according to your app's design.
segment.target: If the event was raised because of socket activity, create a DataReader on the socket, load the reader asynchronously, and then use the data according to your app's design.

segment.source: Note that you must return ownership of the socket back to the socket broker, in order to be notified of further socket activity again.
segment.target: Note that you must return ownership of the socket back to the socket broker, in order to be notified of further socket activity again.

segment.source: In the following example, the text received on the socket is displayed in a toast.
segment.target: In the following example, the text received on the socket is displayed in a toast.

segment.source: If the event was raised because a keep alive timer expired, then your code should send some data over the socket in order to keep the socket alive and restart the keep alive timer.
segment.target: If the event was raised because a keep alive timer expired, then your code should send some data over the socket in order to keep the socket alive and restart the keep alive timer.

segment.source: Again, it is important to return ownership of the socket back to the socket broker in order to receive further event notifications:
segment.target: Again, it is important to return ownership of the socket back to the socket broker in order to receive further event notifications:

segment.source: If the event was raised because the socket was closed, re-establish the socket, making sure that after you create the new socket, you transfer ownership of it to the socket broker.
segment.target: If the event was raised because the socket was closed, re-establish the socket, making sure that after you create the new socket, you transfer ownership of it to the socket broker.

segment.source: In this sample, the hostname and port are stored in local settings so that they can be used to establish a new socket connection:
segment.target: In this sample, the hostname and port are stored in local settings so that they can be used to establish a new socket connection:

segment.source: Don't forget to Complete your deferral, once you have finished processing the event notification:
segment.target: Don't forget to Complete your deferral, once you have finished processing the event notification:

segment.source: For a complete sample demonstrating the use of the SocketActivityTrigger and socket broker, see the SocketActivityStreamSocket sample.
segment.target: For a complete sample demonstrating the use of the SocketActivityTrigger and socket broker, see the SocketActivityStreamSocket sample.

segment.source: The initialization of the socket is performed in Scenario1\_Connect.xaml.cs, and the background task implementation is in SocketActivityTask.cs.
segment.target: The initialization of the socket is performed in Scenario1\_Connect.xaml.cs, and the background task implementation is in SocketActivityTask.cs.

segment.source: You will probably notice that the sample calls TransferOwnership as soon as it creates a new socket or acquires an existing socket, rather than using the OnSuspending even handler to do so as described in this topic.
segment.target: You will probably notice that the sample calls TransferOwnership as soon as it creates a new socket or acquires an existing socket, rather than using the OnSuspending even handler to do so as described in this topic.

segment.source: This is because the sample focuses on demonstrating the SocketActivityTrigger, and doesn't use the socket for any other activity while it is running.
segment.target: This is because the sample focuses on demonstrating the SocketActivityTrigger, and doesn't use the socket for any other activity while it is running.

segment.source: Your app will probably be more complex, and should use OnSuspending to determine when to call TransferOwnership.
segment.target: Your app will probably be more complex, and should use OnSuspending to determine when to call TransferOwnership.

segment.source: Control channel triggers
segment.target: Control channel triggers

segment.source: First, ensure that you're using control channel triggers (CCTs) appropriately.
segment.target: First, ensure that you're using control channel triggers (CCTs) appropriately.

segment.source: If you're using DatagramSocket, StreamSocket, or StreamSocketListener connections, we recommend you use SocketActivityTrigger.
segment.target: If you're using DatagramSocket, StreamSocket, or StreamSocketListener connections, we recommend you use SocketActivityTrigger.

segment.source: You can use CCTs for StreamSocket, but they use more resources and might not work in Connected Standby mode.
segment.target: You can use CCTs for StreamSocket, but they use more resources and might not work in Connected Standby mode.

segment.source: If you are using WebSockets, IXMLHTTPRequest2, System.Net.Http.HttpClient or Windows.Web.Http.HttpClient, you must use ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: If you are using WebSockets, IXMLHTTPRequest2, System.Net.Http.HttpClient or Windows.Web.Http.HttpClient, you must use ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: ControlChannelTrigger with WebSockets
segment.target: ControlChannelTrigger with WebSockets

segment.source: Some special considerations apply when using MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: Some special considerations apply when using MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: There are some transport-specific usage patterns and best practices that should be followed when using a MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: There are some transport-specific usage patterns and best practices that should be followed when using a MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: In addition, these considerations affect the way that requests to receive packets on the StreamWebSocket are handled.
segment.target: In addition, these considerations affect the way that requests to receive packets on the StreamWebSocket are handled.

segment.source: Requests to receive packets on the MessageWebSocket are not affected.
segment.target: Requests to receive packets on the MessageWebSocket are not affected.

segment.source: The following usage patterns and best practices should be followed when using MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket with ControlChannelTrigger:
segment.target: The following usage patterns and best practices should be followed when using MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket with ControlChannelTrigger:

segment.source: An outstanding socket receive must be kept posted at all times.
segment.target: An outstanding socket receive must be kept posted at all times.

segment.source: This is required to allow the push notification tasks to occur.
segment.target: This is required to allow the push notification tasks to occur.

segment.source: The WebSocket protocol defines a standard model for keep-alive messages.
segment.target: The WebSocket protocol defines a standard model for keep-alive messages.

segment.source: The WebSocketKeepAlive class can send client-initiated WebSocket protocol keep-alive messages to the server.
segment.target: The WebSocketKeepAlive class can send client-initiated WebSocket protocol keep-alive messages to the server.

segment.source: The WebSocketKeepAlive class should be registered as the TaskEntryPoint for a KeepAliveTrigger by the app.
segment.target: The WebSocketKeepAlive class should be registered as the TaskEntryPoint for a KeepAliveTrigger by the app.

segment.source: Some special considerations affect the way that requests to receive packets on the StreamWebSocket are handled.
segment.target: Some special considerations affect the way that requests to receive packets on the StreamWebSocket are handled.

segment.source: In particular, when using a StreamWebSocket with the ControlChannelTrigger, your app must use a raw async pattern for handling reads instead of the await model in C# and VB.NET or Tasks in C++.
segment.target: In particular, when using a StreamWebSocket with the ControlChannelTrigger, your app must use a raw async pattern for handling reads instead of the await model in C# and VB.NET or Tasks in C++.

segment.source: The raw async pattern is illustrated in a code sample later in this section.
segment.target: The raw async pattern is illustrated in a code sample later in this section.

segment.source: Using the raw async pattern allows Windows to synchronize the IBackgroundTask.Run method on the background task for the ControlChannelTrigger with the return of the receive completion callback.
segment.target: Using the raw async pattern allows Windows to synchronize the IBackgroundTask.Run method on the background task for the ControlChannelTrigger with the return of the receive completion callback.

segment.source: The Run method is invoked after the completion callback returns.
segment.target: The Run method is invoked after the completion callback returns.

segment.source: This ensures that the app has received the data/errors before the Run method is invoked.
segment.target: This ensures that the app has received the data/errors before the Run method is invoked.

segment.source: It is important to note that the app has to post another read before it returns control from the completion callback.
segment.target: It is important to note that the app has to post another read before it returns control from the completion callback.

segment.source: It is also important to note that the DataReader cannot be directly used with the MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket transport since that breaks the synchronization described above.
segment.target: It is also important to note that the DataReader cannot be directly used with the MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket transport since that breaks the synchronization described above.

segment.source: It is not supported to use the DataReader.LoadAsync method directly on top of the transport.
segment.target: It is not supported to use the DataReader.LoadAsync method directly on top of the transport.

segment.source: Instead, the IBuffer returned by the IInputStream.ReadAsync method on the StreamWebSocket.InputStream property can be later passed to DataReader.FromBuffer method for further processing.
segment.target: Instead, the IBuffer returned by the IInputStream.ReadAsync method on the StreamWebSocket.InputStream property can be later passed to DataReader.FromBuffer method for further processing.

segment.source: The following sample shows how to use a raw async pattern for handling reads on the StreamWebSocket.
segment.target: The following sample shows how to use a raw async pattern for handling reads on the StreamWebSocket.

segment.source: The read completion handler is guaranteed to fire before the IBackgroundTask.Run method on the background task for the ControlChannelTrigger is invoked.
segment.target: The read completion handler is guaranteed to fire before the IBackgroundTask.Run method on the background task for the ControlChannelTrigger is invoked.

segment.source: Windows has internal synchronization to wait for an app to return from the read completion callback.
segment.target: Windows has internal synchronization to wait for an app to return from the read completion callback.

segment.source: The app typically quickly processes the data or the error from the MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket in the read completion callback.
segment.target: The app typically quickly processes the data or the error from the MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket in the read completion callback.

segment.source: The message itself is processed within the context of the IBackgroundTask.Run method.
segment.target: The message itself is processed within the context of the IBackgroundTask.Run method.

segment.source: In this sample below, this point is illustrated by using a message queue that the read completion handler inserts the message into and the background task later processes.
segment.target: In this sample below, this point is illustrated by using a message queue that the read completion handler inserts the message into and the background task later processes.

segment.source: The following sample shows the read completion handler to use with a raw async pattern for handling reads on the StreamWebSocket.
segment.target: The following sample shows the read completion handler to use with a raw async pattern for handling reads on the StreamWebSocket.

segment.source: An additional detail for Websockets is the keep-alive handler.
segment.target: An additional detail for Websockets is the keep-alive handler.

segment.source: The WebSocket protocol defines a standard model for keep-alive messages.
segment.target: The WebSocket protocol defines a standard model for keep-alive messages.

segment.source: When using MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket, register aWebSocketKeepAlive class instance as the TaskEntryPoint for a KeepAliveTrigger to allow the app to be unsuspended and send keep-alive messages to the server (remote endpoint) periodically.
segment.target: When using MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket, register aWebSocketKeepAlive class instance as the TaskEntryPoint for a KeepAliveTrigger to allow the app to be unsuspended and send keep-alive messages to the server (remote endpoint) periodically.

segment.source: This should be done as part of the background registration app code as well as in the package manifest.
segment.target: This should be done as part of the background registration app code as well as in the package manifest.

segment.source: This task entry point of Windows.Sockets.WebSocketKeepAlive needs to be specified in two places:
segment.target: This task entry point of Windows.Sockets.WebSocketKeepAlive needs to be specified in two places:

segment.source: When creating KeepAliveTrigger trigger in the source code (see example below).
segment.target: When creating KeepAliveTrigger trigger in the source code (see example below).

segment.source: In the app package manifest for the keepalive background task declaration.
segment.target: In the app package manifest for the keepalive background task declaration.

segment.source: The following sample adds a network trigger notification and a keepalive trigger under the Application element in an app manifest.
segment.target: The following sample adds a network trigger notification and a keepalive trigger under the Application element in an app manifest.

segment.source: An app must be extremely careful when using an await statement in the context of a ControlChannelTrigger and an asynchronous operation on a StreamWebSocket, MessageWebSocket, or StreamSocket.
segment.target: An app must be extremely careful when using an await statement in the context of a ControlChannelTrigger and an asynchronous operation on a StreamWebSocket, MessageWebSocket, or StreamSocket.

segment.source: A Taskbool object can be used to register a ControlChannelTrigger for push notification and WebSocket keep-alives on the StreamWebSocket and connect the transport.
segment.target: A Taskbool object can be used to register a ControlChannelTrigger for push notification and WebSocket keep-alives on the StreamWebSocket and connect the transport.

segment.source: As part of the registration, the StreamWebSocket transport is set as the transport for the ControlChannelTrigger and a read is posted.
segment.target: As part of the registration, the StreamWebSocket transport is set as the transport for the ControlChannelTrigger and a read is posted.

segment.source: The Task.Result will block the current thread until all steps in the task execute and return statements in message body.
segment.target: The Task.Result will block the current thread until all steps in the task execute and return statements in message body.

segment.source: The task is not resolved until the method returns either true or false.
segment.target: The task is not resolved until the method returns either true or false.

segment.source: This guarantees that the whole method is executed.
segment.target: This guarantees that the whole method is executed.

segment.source: The Task can contain multiple await statements that are protected by the Task.
segment.target: The Task can contain multiple await statements that are protected by the Task.

segment.source: This pattern should be used with the ControlChannelTrigger object when a StreamWebSocket or MessageWebSocket is used as the transport.
segment.target: This pattern should be used with the ControlChannelTrigger object when a StreamWebSocket or MessageWebSocket is used as the transport.

segment.source: For those operations that may take a long period of time to complete (a typical async read operation, for example), the app should use the raw async pattern discussed previously.
segment.target: For those operations that may take a long period of time to complete (a typical async read operation, for example), the app should use the raw async pattern discussed previously.

segment.source: The following sample registers ControlChannelTrigger for push notification and WebSocket keep-alives on the StreamWebSocket.
segment.target: The following sample registers ControlChannelTrigger for push notification and WebSocket keep-alives on the StreamWebSocket.

segment.source: For more information on using MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket with ControlChannelTrigger, see the ControlChannelTrigger StreamWebSocket sample.
segment.target: For more information on using MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket with ControlChannelTrigger, see the ControlChannelTrigger StreamWebSocket sample.

segment.source: ControlChannelTrigger with HttpClient
segment.target: ControlChannelTrigger with HttpClient

segment.source: Some special considerations apply when using HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: Some special considerations apply when using HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: There are some transport-specific usage patterns and best practices that should be followed when using a HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: There are some transport-specific usage patterns and best practices that should be followed when using a HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: In addition, these considerations affect the way that requests to receive packets on the HttpClient are handled.
segment.target: In addition, these considerations affect the way that requests to receive packets on the HttpClient are handled.

segment.source: Note HttpClient using SSL is not currently supported using the network trigger feature and ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: Note HttpClient using SSL is not currently supported using the network trigger feature and ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: The following usage patterns and best practices should be followed when using HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger:
segment.target: The following usage patterns and best practices should be followed when using HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger:

segment.source: The app may need to set various properties and headers on the HttpClient or HttpClientHandler object in the System.Net.Http namespace before sending the request to the specific URI.
segment.target: The app may need to set various properties and headers on the HttpClient or HttpClientHandler object in the System.Net.Http namespace before sending the request to the specific URI.

segment.source: An app may need to make need to an initial request to test and setup the transport properly before creating the HttpClient transport to be used with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: An app may need to make need to an initial request to test and setup the transport properly before creating the HttpClient transport to be used with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: Once the app determines that the transport can be properly setup, an HttpClient object can be configured as the transport object used with the ControlChannelTrigger object.
segment.target: Once the app determines that the transport can be properly setup, an HttpClient object can be configured as the transport object used with the ControlChannelTrigger object.

segment.source: This process is designed prevent some scenarios from breaking the connection established over the transport.
segment.target: This process is designed prevent some scenarios from breaking the connection established over the transport.

segment.source: Using SSL with a certificate, an app may require a dialog to be displayed for PIN entry or if there are multiple certificates to choose from.
segment.target: Using SSL with a certificate, an app may require a dialog to be displayed for PIN entry or if there are multiple certificates to choose from.

segment.source: Proxy authentication and server authentication may be required.
segment.target: Proxy authentication and server authentication may be required.

segment.source: If the proxy or server authentication expires, the connection may be closed.
segment.target: If the proxy or server authentication expires, the connection may be closed.

segment.source: One way an app can deal with these authentication expiration issues is to set a timer.
segment.target: One way an app can deal with these authentication expiration issues is to set a timer.

segment.source: When an HTTP redirect is required, it is not guaranteed that the second connection can be established reliably.
segment.target: When an HTTP redirect is required, it is not guaranteed that the second connection can be established reliably.

segment.source: An initial test request will ensure that the app can use the most up-to-date redirected URL before using the HttpClient object as the transport with the ControlChannelTrigger object.
segment.target: An initial test request will ensure that the app can use the most up-to-date redirected URL before using the HttpClient object as the transport with the ControlChannelTrigger object.

segment.source: Unlike other network transports, the HttpClient object cannot be directly passed into the UsingTransport method of the ControlChannelTrigger object.
segment.target: Unlike other network transports, the HttpClient object cannot be directly passed into the UsingTransport method of the ControlChannelTrigger object.

segment.source: Instead, an HttpRequestMessage object must be specially constructed for use with the HttpClient object and the ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: Instead, an HttpRequestMessage object must be specially constructed for use with the HttpClient object and the ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: The HttpRequestMessage object is created using the RtcRequestFactory.Create method.
segment.target: The HttpRequestMessage object is created using the RtcRequestFactory.Create method.

segment.source: The HttpRequestMessage object that is created is then passed to UsingTransport method .
segment.target: The HttpRequestMessage object that is created is then passed to UsingTransport method .

segment.source: The following sample shows how to construct an HttpRequestMessage object for use with the HttpClient object and the ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: The following sample shows how to construct an HttpRequestMessage object for use with the HttpClient object and the ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: Some special considerations affect the way that requests to send HTTP requests on the HttpClient to initiate receiving a response are handled.
segment.target: Some special considerations affect the way that requests to send HTTP requests on the HttpClient to initiate receiving a response are handled.

segment.source: In particular, when using a HttpClient with the ControlChannelTrigger, your app must use a Task for handling sends instead of the await model.
segment.target: In particular, when using a HttpClient with the ControlChannelTrigger, your app must use a Task for handling sends instead of the await model.

segment.source: Using HttpClient, there is no synchronization with the IBackgroundTask.Run method on the background task for the ControlChannelTrigger with the return of the receive completion callback.
segment.target: Using HttpClient, there is no synchronization with the IBackgroundTask.Run method on the background task for the ControlChannelTrigger with the return of the receive completion callback.

segment.source: For this reason, the app can only use the blocking HttpResponseMessage technique in the Run method and wait until the whole response is received.
segment.target: For this reason, the app can only use the blocking HttpResponseMessage technique in the Run method and wait until the whole response is received.

segment.source: Using HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger is noticeably different from the StreamSocket, MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket transports .
segment.target: Using HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger is noticeably different from the StreamSocket, MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket transports .

segment.source: The HttpClient receive callback is delivered via a Task to the app since the HttpClient code.
segment.target: The HttpClient receive callback is delivered via a Task to the app since the HttpClient code.

segment.source: This means that the ControlChannelTrigger push notification task will fire as soon as the data or error is dispatched to the app.
segment.target: This means that the ControlChannelTrigger push notification task will fire as soon as the data or error is dispatched to the app.

segment.source: In the sample below, the code stores the responseTask returned by HttpClient.SendAsync method into global storage that the push notify task will pick up and process inline.
segment.target: In the sample below, the code stores the responseTask returned by HttpClient.SendAsync method into global storage that the push notify task will pick up and process inline.

segment.source: The following sample shows how to handle send requests on the HttpClient when used with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: The following sample shows how to handle send requests on the HttpClient when used with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: The following sample shows how to read responses received on the HttpClient when used with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: The following sample shows how to read responses received on the HttpClient when used with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: For more information on using HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger, see the ControlChannelTrigger HttpClient sample.
segment.target: For more information on using HttpClient with ControlChannelTrigger, see the ControlChannelTrigger HttpClient sample.

segment.source: ControlChannelTrigger with IXMLHttpRequest2
segment.target: ControlChannelTrigger with IXMLHttpRequest2

segment.source: Some special considerations apply when using IXMLHTTPRequest2 with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: Some special considerations apply when using IXMLHTTPRequest2 with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: There are some transport-specific usage patterns and best practices that should be followed when using a IXMLHTTPRequest2 with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: There are some transport-specific usage patterns and best practices that should be followed when using a IXMLHTTPRequest2 with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: Using ControlChannelTrigger does not affect the way that requests to send or receive HTTP requests on the IXMLHTTPRequest2 are handled.
segment.target: Using ControlChannelTrigger does not affect the way that requests to send or receive HTTP requests on the IXMLHTTPRequest2 are handled.

segment.source: Usage patterns and best practices when using IXMLHTTPRequest2 with ControlChannelTrigger
segment.target: Usage patterns and best practices when using IXMLHTTPRequest2 with ControlChannelTrigger

segment.source: An IXMLHTTPRequest2 object when used as the transport has a lifetime of only one request/response.
segment.target: An IXMLHTTPRequest2 object when used as the transport has a lifetime of only one request/response.

segment.source: When used with the ControlChannelTrigger object, it is convenient to create and set up the ControlChannelTrigger object once and then call the UsingTransport method repeatedly, each time associating a new IXMLHTTPRequest2 object.
segment.target: When used with the ControlChannelTrigger object, it is convenient to create and set up the ControlChannelTrigger object once and then call the UsingTransport method repeatedly, each time associating a new IXMLHTTPRequest2 object.

segment.source: An app should delete the previous IXMLHTTPRequest2 object before supplying a new IXMLHTTPRequest2 object to ensure that the app does not exceed the allocated resource limits.
segment.target: An app should delete the previous IXMLHTTPRequest2 object before supplying a new IXMLHTTPRequest2 object to ensure that the app does not exceed the allocated resource limits.

segment.source: The app may need to call the SetProperty and SetRequestHeader methods to set up the HTTP transport before calling Send method.
segment.target: The app may need to call the SetProperty and SetRequestHeader methods to set up the HTTP transport before calling Send method.

segment.source: An app may need to make need to an initial Send request to test and setup the transport properly before creating the transport to be used with ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: An app may need to make need to an initial Send request to test and setup the transport properly before creating the transport to be used with ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: Once the app determines that the transport is properly setup, the IXMLHTTPRequest2 object can be configured as the transport object used with the ControlChannelTrigger.
segment.target: Once the app determines that the transport is properly setup, the IXMLHTTPRequest2 object can be configured as the transport object used with the ControlChannelTrigger.

segment.source: This process is designed prevent some scenarios from breaking the connection established over the transport.
segment.target: This process is designed prevent some scenarios from breaking the connection established over the transport.

segment.source: Using SSL with a certificate, an app may require a dialog to be displayed for PIN entry or if there are multiple certificates to choose from.
segment.target: Using SSL with a certificate, an app may require a dialog to be displayed for PIN entry or if there are multiple certificates to choose from.

segment.source: Proxy authentication and server authentication may be required.
segment.target: Proxy authentication and server authentication may be required.

segment.source: If the proxy or server authentication expires, the connection may be closed.
segment.target: If the proxy or server authentication expires, the connection may be closed.

segment.source: One way an app can deal with these authentication expiration issues is to set a timer.
segment.target: One way an app can deal with these authentication expiration issues is to set a timer.

segment.source: When an HTTP redirect is required, it is not guaranteed that the second connection can be established reliably.
segment.target: When an HTTP redirect is required, it is not guaranteed that the second connection can be established reliably.

segment.source: An initial test request will ensure that the app can use the most up-to-date redirected URL before using the IXMLHTTPRequest2 object as the transport with the ControlChannelTrigger object.
segment.target: An initial test request will ensure that the app can use the most up-to-date redirected URL before using the IXMLHTTPRequest2 object as the transport with the ControlChannelTrigger object.

segment.source: For more information on using IXMLHTTPRequest2 with ControlChannelTrigger, see the ControlChannelTrigger with IXMLHTTPRequest2 sample.
segment.target: For more information on using IXMLHTTPRequest2 with ControlChannelTrigger, see the ControlChannelTrigger with IXMLHTTPRequest2 sample.
